categories.name: Plastic
categories.desc: To determine the type of plastic, look at the bottom of the container for a number inside the triangle recycling symbol. Please rinse containers and remove lids. #1 PETE Plastic YES: #1 plastic containers (eg. soda and water bottles). NO: Plastic bags, plastics #2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7, polystyrene (Styrofoam), or any unlabeled plastic. Clear #2 HDPE Plastic YES: #2 clear plastic containers (eg. milk and juice jugs). NO: Plastic bags, plastics #1, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7, polystyrene (Styrofoam), or any unlabeled plastic. Colored #2 HDPE Plastic and Plastics #3 - #7 YES: White or colored plastics labeled #2 HDPE (eg. laundry detergent bottles), plastic bottles and containers labeled #3 (V), #4 (LDPE), #5 (PP), #6 (PS), and #7 (Other). NO: Plastic bags, expanded polystyrene (aka Styrofoam), or any unlabeled plastic. Plastic Bags YES: Clean plastic grocery or merchandise bags, dry cleaning bags, and bubble wrap. NO: Foam, rigid containers, paper, food or liquids, polystyrene packaging, strapping, or twine.

categories.name: Metal
categories.desc: Aluminum Cans YES: All aluminum cans. NO: Aluminum foil, scrap aluminum, tin cans Aluminum Foil YES: Aluminum foil, pie plates. Please rinse. NO: No foiled lined bags i.e. potato chip bags, aluminum cans, tin cans, scrap metal. Tin Cans and Scrap Metal YES: Tin Cans, scrap aluminum, brass, copper, steel, small appliances. NO: Hazardous materials, non-metal products (plastic, rubber), large appliances or items that contain freon

categories.name: Glass
categories.desc: Clear Glass YES: All clear jars and bottles. NO: Vases, auto glass, ceramics (i.e. mugs, plates), light bulbs, mirrors, drinking glass, plates, plate glass, or Pyrex. These cause major contamination issues! Brown Glass YES: All brown jars and bottles. NO: Vases, auto glass, ceramics (i.e. mugs, plates), light bulbs, mirrors, drinking glass, plates, plate glass, or Pyrex. These cause major contamination issues! Green and Blue Glass YES: All green and blue jars and bottles. NO: Vases, auto glass, ceramics (i.e. mugs, plates), light bulbs, mirrors, drinking glass, plates, plate glass, or Pyrex. These cause major contamination issues!

categories.name: Paper
categories.desc: Corrugated Cardboard YES: Corrugated cardboard (with wavy piece in the middle) and brown paper bags. NO: File folders, pizza or donut boxes, paper board (eg. cereal boxes), waxy or plasticized paperboard. Magazines YES: Magazines and catalogs. NO: Colored paper, mixed paper, paper bags, TV guides. Mixed Paper YES: All Paper including junk mail, phone books, white paper, computer paper, colored paper, shredded paper, hard and soft backed books, aseptic containers (juice and milk cartons and soy milk containers, and drink boxes), and newspapers and magazines. NO: Food contaminated paper like pizza or donut boxes, corrugated cardboard, waxy or plasticized paperboard. Newspaper YES: Newspaper and newspaper inserts. NO: Magazines, mixed paper, paper bags, phone books.

categories.name: Electronic
categories.desc: Electronics typically cannot be recycled at curbside pickup. Depending on what the item is, it can be taken to a drop off location or certain retailers like best buy offer electronic waste recycling and disposal

recyclables.name: Bottle
recyclables.desc: Bottles are commonly plastic or glass and are recycleable.
recyclables.body: Bottles are commonly plastic or glass. They can be recycled in common recycling bins or with your regular recycling pick up. Leave lids on because plastic lids and caps are small and might get mixed in with the wrong material in the sorting process if they are not attached to the larger bottle. Leave labels on In the early days of recycling, labels were a problem, but this is no longer the case.

recyclables.name: Magazines
recyclables.desc: No, you can't recycle this. Sorry!

recyclables.name: Battery
recyclables.body: Alkaline Batteries (Single use) Single-use batteries (A, AA, AAA, C, D, etc.) can be thrown out in your regular garbage or can be recycled for a fee through a variety of mail in programs or local retail drop offs. Recycling these batteries through mail-in or retail drop off programs can recover steel and zinc. Never put these batteries in your recycling cart. Car Batteries (Lead Acid Batteries) Can be recycled. Take to recycling drop off location or often vendors that sell car batteries will offer a discount to take in and recycle old ones. Do not throw in the garbage or household recycling pick up, in the state of Wisconsin lead-acid batteries must be recycled. Phone Batteries and other Recharageable Batteries. Rechargeable batteries (NiCd, NiMH, NiZn, Li-ion, SSLA/Pb) Can be taken to stores like office depot, best buy, or UPS store locations to be recycled.For a complete list visit Call 2 Recycle's database. Rechargeable batteries contain toxic chemistries and should be recycled instead of being placed in the garbage.
